title: 108_hr1051
content: The Act titled "Pioneer National Historic Trails Studies Act" is introduced to revise feasibility and suitability studies of existing national historic trails for possible trail expansion. The Act titled "Pioneer National Historic Trails Studies Act" aims to define terms like 'route' and 'shared route' and sets out general rules for conducting studies on historic trails. The Secretary is required to complete and submit these studies to Congress within three fiscal years of the enactment of the section. The Secretary of the Interior is mandated to conduct a study on various routes of the Oregon Trail to assess their feasibility for designation as components of the Oregon National Historic Trail. The study must be completed and submitted to Congress within three fiscal years of the enactment of the law. The Secretary of the Interior will conduct a study on the southern alternative route of the Pony Express Trail and other routes to determine their suitability for designation as components of the Pony Express National Historic Trail. Additionally, a study will be undertaken on certain routes of the California Trail for possible inclusion in the California National Historic Trail. The Secretary of the Interior will conduct a study on various Missouri Valley routes, including Blue Mills-Independence Road and Fort Leavenworth-Blue River route, for possible designation as components of the California National Historic Trail. The Secretary of the Interior will conduct a study on various Missouri Valley routes, including Blue Mills-Independence Road and Fort Leavenworth-Blue River route, for possible designation as components of the California National Historic Trail. The routes include Lower Bellevue, Woodbury, Blue Ridge, Westport Road, Gum Springs-Fort Leavenworth, Atchison/Independence Creek, Fort Leavenworth-Kansas River, Nebraska City cutoff, Minersville-Nebraska City Road, Upper Plattsmouth, Upper Bellevue, Cherokee Trail, Weber Canyon route of Hastings cutoff, Bishop Creek, McAuley, Diamond Springs, Secret Pass, and Greenhorn cutoff. The Secretary of the Interior will conduct a study on various Western routes, including Bidwell-Bartleson route, Georgetown/Dagget Pass Trail, Big Trees Road, Grizzly Flat cutoff, Nevada City Road, Yreka Trail, Henness Pass route, Johnson cutoff, Luther Pass Trail, Volcano Road, Sacramento-Coloma Wagon Road, Burnett cutoff, and Placer County Road to Auburn for possible designation as components of the California National Historic Trail. Additionally, a study will be undertaken on certain routes of the Mormon Pioneer Trail. The Secretary of the Interior will conduct a study on various Western routes, including Bidwell-Bartleson route, Georgetown/Dagget Pass Trail, Big Trees Road, Grizzly Flat cutoff, Nevada City Road, Yreka Trail, Henness Pass route, Johnson cutoff, Luther Pass Trail, Volcano Road, Sacramento-Coloma Wagon Road, Burnett cutoff, and Placer County Road to Auburn for possible designation as components of the California National Historic Trail. The study will also include routes of the Mormon Pioneer Trail such as 1846 Subsequent routes A and B, 1856-57 Handcart route, Keokuk route, 1847 Alternative Elkhorn and Loup River Crossings in Nebraska, Fort Leavenworth Road, 1850 Golden Pass Road in Utah. The Secretary of the Interior will study shared routes of the California Trail and Oregon Trail for possible designation as components of the California National Historic Trail and the Oregon National Historic Trail. Routes to be studied include St. Joe Road, Council Bluffs Road, Sublette cutoff, Applegate route, Old Fort Kearny Road, Childs cutoff, and Raft River to Applegate.
